◆ RETURN_ON_ERROR

#define RETURN_ON_ERROR (   x)
Value:
if ((x) != AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS) \
{ \
return (x); \
};
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS
@ AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS
Definition: am_hal_status.h:63

Convenience macro for passing errors.

◆ SCARD_SYNC_OPER

#define SCARD_SYNC_OPER (   module,
  operation 
)
Value:
do{\
SCARDn(module)->SR1_b.SYNCEND = 1;\
operation;\
SCARD_WHILE_TIMEOUT_MS(!SCARDn(module)->SR1_b.SYNCEND, SCARD_MAX_SYNC_TIME_MS, AM_HAL_SCARD_STATUS_BUS_ERROR) ;\
} while ( 0 )

◆ SCARD_WHILE_TIMEOUT_MS

#define SCARD_WHILE_TIMEOUT_MS (   expr,
  timeout,
  error 
)
Value:
{ \
uint32_t ui32Timeout = 0; \
while ( expr ) \
{ \
if ( ui32Timeout == (timeout * 1000) ) \
{ \
return error; \
} \
\
delay_us(1); \
ui32Timeout++; \
} \
}

◆ am_hal_scard_configure()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_configure ( void *  pHandle,
am_hal_scard_config_t *  psConfig 
)

Used to configure basic SCARD settings.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
psConfig- a structure of SCARD configuration options.

This function takes the options from an am_hal_scard_config_t structure, and applies them to the SCARD referred to by pHandle.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_deinitialize()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_deinitialize ( void *  pHandle)

Deinitialize the SCARD interface.

Parameters
pHandle- a previously initialized SCARD handle.

This function effectively disables future calls to interact with the SCARD refered to by pHandle. The user may call this function if SCARD operation is no longer desired.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

uint32_t am_hal_scard_initialize ( uint32_t  ui32Module,
void **  ppHandle 
)

Initialize the SCARD interface.

Parameters
ui32Module- the module number for the SCARD to initialize.
ppHandle- the location to write the SCARD handle.

This function sets internal tracking variables associated with a specific SCARD module. It should be the first SCARD API called for each SCARD module in use. The handle can be used to interact with the SCARD

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_interrupt_clear()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_interrupt_clear ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Index,
uint32_t  ui32IntMask 
)

Clear interrupt status.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ui32Index- SR(0) or SR1
ui32IntMask- the bitmask of interrupts to clear.

This function clears the SCARD interrupt(s) given by ui32IntMask. If multiple interrupts need to be cleared, they can be OR'ed together.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

◆ am_hal_scard_interrupt_disable()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_interrupt_disable ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Index,
uint32_t  ui32IntMask 
)

Disable interrupts.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ui32Index- IER(0) or IER1
ui32IntMask- the bitmask of interrupts to disable.

This function disables the SCARD interrupt(s) given by ui32IntMask. If multiple interrupts need to be disabled, they can be OR'ed together.

Note
This function need not be called for SCARD FIFO interrupts if the SCARD buffer service provided by am_hal_scard_buffer_configure() and am_hal_scard_interrupt_service() is already in use. Non-FIFO-related interrupts do require the use of this function.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FHFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FT2RENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_OVREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FEREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_TBERBFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FNEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_SYNCENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PRLEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_ECNTOVEREN
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_interrupt_enable()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_interrupt_enable ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Index,
uint32_t  ui32IntMask 
)

Enable interrupts.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ui32Index- IER(0) or IER1
ui32IntMask- is the bitmask of interrupts to enable.

This function enables the SCARD interrupt(s) given by ui32IntMask. If multiple interrupts are desired, they can be OR'ed together.

Note
This function need not be called for SCARD FIFO interrupts if the SCARD buffer service provided by am_hal_scard_buffer_configure() and am_hal_scard_interrupt_service() is already in use. Non-FIFO-related interrupts do require the use of this function.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FHFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FT2RENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_OVREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FEREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_TBERBFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FNEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_SYNCENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PRLEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_ECNTOVEREN
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_interrupt_service()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_interrupt_service ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Status,
uint32_t *  pui32ScardTxIdle 
)

This function handles the SCARD buffers during SCARD interrupts.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ui32Status- The interrupt status at the time of ISR entry.
pui32ScardTxIdle- Can be used to store the SCARD idle status.

The main purpose of this function is to manage the SCARD buffer system. Any buffers configured by am_hal_scard_buffer_configure will be managed by this service routine. Data queued for transmit will be added to the SCARD TX FIFO as space allows, and data stored in the SCARD RX FIFO will be copied out and stored in the RX buffer. This function will skip this transfer for any buffer that has not been configured.

In addition, this function can be used to alert the caller when the SCARD becomes idle via the optional pui32ScardTxIdle argument. This function will set this variable any time it completes its operation and the SCARD TX channel is no longer in use (including both the FIFO and any configured buffer).

For RTOS-enabled cases, this function does not necessarily need to be called inside the actual ISR for the SCARD, but it should be called promptly in response to the receipt of a SCARD TX, RX, or RX timeout interrupt. If the service routine is not called quickly enough, the caller risks an RX FIFO overflow (data can be lost here), or a TX FIFO underflow (usually not harmful).

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_interrupt_status_get()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_interrupt_status_get ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Index,
uint32_t *  pui32Status 
)

Read interrupt status.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ui32Index- SR(0) or SR1
pui32Status- the returned interrupt status (all bits OR'ed together)

This function reads the status the SCARD interrupt(s) if bEnabled is true, it will only return the status of the enabled interrupts. Otherwise, it will return the status of all interrupts, enabled or disabled.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FHFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FT2RENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_OVREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FEREN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_TBERBFEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_FNEEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_SYNCENDEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_PRLEN
AM_HAL_SCARD_INT_ECNTOVEREN
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_power_control()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_power_control ( void *  pHandle,
am_hal_sysctrl_power_state_e  ePowerState,
bool  bRetainState 
)

Change the power state of the SCARD module.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
ePowerState- the desired power state of the SCARD.
bRetainState- a flag to ask the HAL to save SCARD registers.

This function can be used to switch the power to the SCARD on or off. If bRetainState is true during a powerdown operation, it will store the SCARD configuration registers to SRAM, so it can restore them on power-up.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_transfer()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_transfer ( void *  pHandle,
const am_hal_scard_transfer_t *  pTransfer 
)

Transfer data through the SCARD interface.

Parameters
pHandle- the handle for the SCARD to operate on.
pTransfer- a structure describing the operation.

This function executes a transaction as described by the am_hal_scard_transfer_t structure. It can either read or write, and it will take advantage of any buffer space provided by the am_hal_scard_configure() function.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.

◆ am_hal_scard_tx_flush()

uint32_t am_hal_scard_tx_flush ( void *  pHandle)

Wait for the SCARD TX to become idle.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the SCARD to operate on.

This function waits (polling) for all data in the SCARD TX FIFO and SCARD TX buffer (if configured) to be fully sent on the physical SCARD interface. This is not the most power-efficient way to wait for SCARD idle, but it can be useful in simpler applications, or where power-efficiency is less important.

Once this function returns, the SCARD can be safely disabled without interfering with any previous transmissions.

Note
For a more power-efficient way to shut down the SCARD, check the am_hal_scard_interrupt_service() function.
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable SCARD errors.
